## Microhabitat

> Physical habitat variables measured at each frog

 - [*Quantitative*]{.purple}: local velocity, depth, channel width
 - [*Categorical*]{.purple}: dominant substrate, cover, geomorphic unit, hydraulic unit, reach type, riparian type

::: {.fragment}
![](../img/habitat_breeding_rabo.jpg){.absolute left=0 bottom=0 width=30%}

![](../img/hab_campck02.jpg){.absolute right=0 bottom=0 width=30%}
:::

## Microhabitat Associations 

:::{.incremental}
 - While RABO use a wide array of habitat, local hydraulic conditions are main physical control on breeding and rearing habitat
 - Egg and tadpoles are susceptible to scour / dessication from high velocities or stage drops
 - Predictability and variability (heterogeneity) are important
:::

## Habitat Suitability Criteria {.smaller}

::: {.columns .pv4}

::: {.column .pr4 width="40%" .incremental}

 - Use vs. Available habitat clearly shows preference for low-velocity/depth

 - 90% of eggs observed in Sierras were in shallow, sheltered waters (n=147) (Bondi et al. 2013)
    - < 0.67 m total depth
    - < 0.15 m/s velocity

## Reach Heterogeneity

::: {.columns}

::: {.column .pr4 width="45%"}

 - Compared 10 study reaches, Shannons Diversity Index key predictor of frog abundance (Yarnell 2008)
 - Habitat diversity within a reach matters

:::
::: {.column .pr4 width="55%"}
![Yarnell 2008](../img/yarnell_2008_shannons.png){fig-align="center"}
:::
:::

## River Network Heterogeneity {.smaller background-image="../img/azimuth_inset_map_nfamerican.png" background-size="cover" background-color="#000000"}

## Network Heterogeneity {.smaller background-image="../img/peek_2010_conf_fig.png" background-size="50%" background-position="right" background-color="#000000"}

::: {.columns}

::: {.column .f2 .pr4 width="45%" .incremental}

 - Not only does the diversity of habitats within a reach matter, but the location of the reach within the stream network matters. 
 - Frogs occur closer to confluences than random or “expected” (Peek 2010)
 - Confluences are known to have higher diversity of habitats and create refugia

:::

:::

::: notes

Frogs associate with stream reaches of greater physical habitat heterogeneity

Analysing the complexity of geomorphic units at the reach scale is appropriate for this species

:::

## Adult Habitat {.smaller}

::: {.incremental}

 - Most common along pool, glide, or riffles (Lind and Yarnell 2008, Bourque 2008, Haggarty 2006, Yarnell 2005, Van Wagner 1996, Lind 2005)
 - Near stream cover may include wide array from shoreline rocks (especially cobble), to leaf litter, or overhanging vegetation [e.g. Carex sp.] (Bourque 2008, Haggarty 2006, Yarnell 2005, Hayes and Jennings 1988, Van Wagner 1996)
 - Adults may prefer some riparian overhanging vegetation (e.g. Carex sp.) with moderate shade (Van Wagner 1996, Zweifel 1955, Moyle 1973, Hayes and Jennings 1988)

:::

<br>
[**So pretty much all the possibilities!**]{.tc .f1 .blue .fragment}

Rana boylii have been documented in a wide range of habitats, but all generally occur within a short distance of flowing water (see Bourque 2008) although differences appear to vary both regionally and seasonally (Bourque 2008, Haggarty 2006, Van Wagner 1996, Yarnell 2000, Yarnell 2005).

::: footer
Habitat: Breeding

::: notes
Eggs Suitable Water Depths:
 - 10-13 cm (Fitch 1936)
 - 7-22 cm (Fuller and Lind 1992)
 - 4-43 cm (Kupferberg 1996 & 1997)
 - 6-28 cm (Van Wagner 1996)
 - 6-40 cm (Lind 2005)
 - Eggs: 90% found in 14-67 cm (Yarnell et al. 2011)

Early Stage Tadpoles (90% within): 1-54 cm, Late Stage Tadpoles (90% within): 1-51 cm (Yarnell et al. 2011)
 - Suitable Water Velocity:
 - 0.0-0.06 m/s (Fuller and Lind 1992)
 - 0.01-0.14 m/s (Kupferberg 1996 & 1997)
 - 0.0-0.03 m/s (Van Wagner 1996)
 - 0.00-0.21 m/s (Lind 2005)
 - 0.04-0.17 m/s (Wheeler and Welsh 2008)
 - Eggs: 90% found in 0.00-0.15 m/s (Yarnell et al. 2011)
 - Early Stage Tadpoles (90% within): 0.00-0.16 m/s, Late Stage Tadpoles (90% within): 0.00-0.12 m/s (Yarnell et al. 2011)
 - Critical velocities ranged from 0.01-0.04 m/s depending on developmental state, body size, and population of origin (Kupferberg et al. 2009c)
Substrate: most common – cobbles and boulders, "clean" (no algae/sediment) surface for egg attachment (Kupferberg 1996 & 1997, Van Wagner 1996, Lind 2005, Wheeler et al. 2003)

:::

## Overwintering Habitat {.smaller}

::: {.columns .pv4}
::: {.column width="70%" .incremental}
 
 - Very little data are available relating to overwintering habitat
 - Van Wagner (1996) observed *R. boylii* both in the water and along the stream-edge habitat beneath rocks, leaf litter, and Carex sp
 - Also found frogs appeared to be active whenever ambient conditions were favorable
 - Habitat use in large rivers may vary, juveniles & adults may move into smaller lateral tributaries to avoid risk of scouring (Kupferberg 1996)
 - Or move into adjacent terrestrial habitat to avoid winter flood events altogether.
 
:::
